architecture /ˈɑːrkɪtektʃər/
Architecture is the design and form of a building.
The Sydney Opera House is a good example of modern architecture.
basket /ˈbæskɪt/
A basket is a container made of woven materials that is used to carry things.
He put the vegetables in a basket.
bloom /bluːm/
To bloom is to produce an open flower.
The white daisies were about to bloom.
canoe /kəˈnuː/
A canoe is a long, light boat with pointed ends.
He paddled his canoe to the edge of the lake.
carpet /ˈkɑːrpɪt/
A carpet is a thick, heavy, woven fabric used to cover the floor.
His white living room carpet was soft.
cousin /ˈkʌzn/
A cousin is the child of one’s aunt and uncle.
My cousin looks just like me.
desk /desk/
A desk is a piece of furniture that people sit at to do work.
She put the books on her desk.
gallery /ˈɡæləri/
A gallery is a large space where people can see works of art.
The art gallery displayed beautiful paintings.
guest /ɡest/
A guest is someone who is invited to an event, occasion, or location.
Alice invited a special guest for dinner.
host /həʊst/
A host is someone who invites a guest someplace.
He was a gracious host.
july /dʒuːlái/
The seventh month of the year is July.
Her birthday is in July.
modern /ˈmɑːdərn/
A modern thing belongs to the current time.
The kitchen had a modern look.
museum /mjuˈziːəm/
Amuseum is a building that displays cultural, social, and scientific objects.
The Louvre is a famous museum in France.
pink /pɪŋk/
Pink is a pale shade of red.
She chose a pink lipstick.
plane /pleɪn/
A plane is a vehicle that has an engine and wings and flies in the air.
They took a plane across the ocean to India.
refrigerator /rɪˈfrɪdʒəreɪtər/
A refrigerator is a large electrical machine used to keep food cold.
He kept milk, eggs, and butter in the refrigerator.
temperature /ˈtemprətʃər/
A temperature is a measure of how hot or cold something is.
In the winter, the temperature can drop below 0 degrees.
theater /θíːətər/
A theater is a place where people can watch movies or live shows.
He took her to see a comedy show at the theater.
upper /ˈʌpər/
An upper position is a higher position.
He took the elevator to the upper floor.
welcome /ˈwelkəm/
To welcome is to greet someone or something with pleasure.
She greeted her friends with a warm welcome.
